Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor arranged a short meeting in an otherwise packed day.
Situation2: The taxi driver ensures the cab remains neat and hygienic.
Story: I glanced at my phone, heart pounding. My mentor had just texted, “I can meet for 15 minutes at 2:00 PM. Sorry, that’s all I have today.” I knew how rare these windows were—he was always busy, and I’d promised myself I’d never waste his time. But as I pulled up to the curb, my last passenger stepped out, leaving behind a mess: spilled coffee pooling on the seat, napkins crumpled on the floor. I had another ride request already pinging, and if I didn’t clean up, my rating—and reputation as a professional taxi driver—would take a hit. But if I stopped to clean, I’d be late for my mentor, disrespecting the one thing I’d sworn to honor: his time. My hands shook as I stared at the mess, torn between the cab and the clock, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, demanding more than I could give.
